qas.question: What uses a combination of genes to form new shoots?
What were plant parts like in their primitive days?

answers.text: separate from (but in contact with) each other

qas.question: What did some plant parts do as they evolved?
What is a term for a plant with a specific sex per flower?
What was dominated by the male parts?
How did flowers tend to grow when they were male dominant?
What did some plant parts do when the flower had only male parts?
During flower ontogeny, what was a plant of a specific sex called?
What do ovary inferior plants use to form new shoots?

context: <a0_0>Flower ontogeny<a0_0/> uses <b9_0>a combination of genes<b9_0/> normally responsible for forming new shoots. The most primitive flowers probably had a variable number of flower parts, often <a1_0>separate from (but in contact with) each other<a1_0/>. The <b5_0>flowers<b5_0/> tended to <a2_0>grow <b6_0>in a spiral pattern<b6_0/><a2_0/>, to be bisexual (in plants, this means both male and female parts on the same flower), and to be dominated by the ovary (female part). As flowers evolved, some variations developed parts <a3_0><b7_0>fused together<b7_0/><a3_0/>, with a much more specific number and design, and with either specific sexes per flower or plant or at least <a4_0><b8_0>"ovary-inferior"<b8_0/><a4_0/>.
